ðŸŒŸ wallrice | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Transforming user-uploaded images into stylized wallpapers by applying custom or thematic color palettes.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Built-in Color Palettes â€¢ Custom Color Selection â€¢ Advanced Colorization Settings â€¢ Realistic Device Previews â€¢ Terminal Simulation
ðŸ“– Summary: WallRice is a modern web application that allows users to colorize their uploaded images and wallpapers using custom or pre-defined color palettes. It offers advanced settings for fine-tuning the colorization process and provides realistic previews within device mockups.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ spotatui | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: To provide a fully functional and resource-efficient Spotify client experience directly within the command-line interface, enabling users to control music playback, view lyrics, and visualize audio without needing a separate graphical application or daemon.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Standalone Spotify client for the terminal â€¢ Native streaming, no daemon required â€¢ Real-time audio visualization â€¢ Synced lyrics support â€¢ Lightweight and performant (low RAM usage)
ðŸ“– Summary: Spotatui is a standalone, native Spotify client for the terminal, built with Rust and powered by Ratatui. It offers a lightweight and efficient way to interact with Spotify directly from your command line, featuring real-time audio visualization and synced lyrics.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ pingerr | Shell
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Finding the most optimal DNS server for a router or machine by benchmarking public DNS resolvers.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Tests 60+ DNS Servers â€¢ Multiple Test Iterations â€¢ DNS-Ping Correlation Analysis â€¢ Smart Scoring System â€¢ Color-Coded Results
ðŸ“– Summary: Pingerr is a shell script that benchmarks over 60 public DNS servers to identify the fastest and most reliable option for your network. It analyzes DNS query times and network latency, providing a weighted score and color-coded results for easy interpretation.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ MK_DroidScreenCast | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: To provide a user-friendly interface for remotely controlling and streaming an Android device's screen to a PC, simplifying the process of debugging, development, or general usage.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Universal Android device manager using ADB and Scrcpy â€¢ Control smartphone from PC via USB or Wi-Fi â€¢ Interactive CLI and modern Web Panel interfaces â€¢ Automatic environment setup and tool downloads (ADB, Scrcpy)
ðŸ“– Summary: MK DroidScreenCast is a Python-based application that provides full access to an Android smartphone via ADB and Scrcpy. It offers both a command-line interface (CLI) and a web-based panel for managing and streaming the Android device's screen to a PC over USB or Wi-Fi.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ python-cqrs | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Implementing CQRS and event-driven architectures in Python applications for distributed systems.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ CQRS pattern implementation â€¢ Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) support â€¢ Event Sourcing â€¢ Transaction Outbox pattern â€¢ Saga pattern orchestration
ðŸ“– Summary: Python CQRS is a framework for implementing the Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern in Python applications. It facilitates the separation of read and write operations, enhancing scalability, performance, and maintainability, with added support for event-driven architecture concepts like event sourcing, sagas, and transaction outbox patterns.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source
